MUSIC: OPENING TITLES
1. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY OPERATING ROOM
FX: HUMMING EQUIPMENT. THE BLEEP OF A BRAINWAVE MONITOR.
(GROGGY AND FRIGHTENED) No — please... Reev, what are you doing?
There’s no need to be alarmed, Lizzo. The procedure will be over soon.
Everything’s numb. Why’s everything numb?
You've been sedated for your own good. Now, I promise you, this won’t hurt.
(FX: EQUIPMENT OPERATED — UNPLEASANTLY LIKE A DENTIST’S DRILL CROSSED WITH A BLOWTORCH. )
Well, perhaps just a little...
(SCREAMS) No — no!!!
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 3
2. EXT. CAMPUS COURTYARD — DAY

(FX: THE CAMPUS OF A GALACTIC UNIVERSITY. DISTANT CHATTER AND LAUGHTER OF STUDENTS — A HUGE VARIETY OF LIFE FORMS, SO LOTS OF ‘ALIEN’ TYPE VOICES ETC THROUGHOUT. WE ARE IN A FAIRLY QUIET AREA, AS: THE TARDIS MATERIALISES. DOORS OPEN. THE DOCTOR AND
EMERGE. )
Ah, taste that air!
Les Just... air. Tsn’ t: 1?
Just air? It is the air of learning. The atmosphere of erudition. The oxygen of wisdom. Oh yes, this is the place all right.
It looks like we’re between a municipal building and a public toilet.
That is because I have cleverly landed the TARDIS out of sight so as to avoid attracting attention.
(LOW) It’s not the TARDIS we need to keep out of sight.
Can’t afford to be mobbed by autograph hunters and press photographers as soon as we arrive, can we. Come on...
THEY MOVE OFF:
(CONT’D)
And I heard that. I was just treating it with the contempt such a remark deserves.
STAY WITH THEM AS THEY WALK. MIKLEV PUSHES PAST.
Excuse me — can I just..? Thanks!
(BARGED) Oof! — Charming!
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 4
I think he was in a hurry.
Evidently.
Doctor, are you sure we’re in the right place?
What does that say? That sign — yes, there. Read it. Out loud, if you please.
‘Penalty for littering — [one hundred credits’ ]
Not that one. The sign, with the arrow, pointing... Oh, never mind.
‘Vice Chancellor’s Office.’
Yes, thank you, I can read. The point is — where do you get a Vice Chancellor?
A university.
A university. And in this case, not just any university, but one of [the most prestigious... ]
(PARROTING) .. the most prestigious academic institutions in the galaxy.
Yes, this is the CAGE.
The what?
The College of Advanced Galactic Education. One of the most prestigious — etcetera etcetera.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 5
And this Cage place has given you an award.
An award? An award?! They have bestowed upon my humble self an honorary degree in Moral Philosophy.
Moral Philosophy? What’s that?
Well, I’m not quite sure actually. But I’m certain it’s well
deserved.
For doing what?
No idea. But the Vice Chancellor should know. He invited me here.
FX: THEY MOVE ON, FADING AS THEY GO:
So how did they get in touch?
I keep a post office box in Reigate.
Reigate? Why?
So people can get in touch. Come on, Peri — keep up. Anyone would think you were embarrassed to be seen with me...
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 6
3. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY OPERATING ROOM — DAY
FX: THE DRILL-BLOWTORCH STOPS.
BREATHING HEAVILY, IN PAIN
That’s the primary phase complete.
My head... Reev — please... What have you done to my head?
Once your alpha-wave readings have returned to an acceptable level we can [move to phase 2]
(FX: HE BREAKS OFF AS LIZZO HURLS HERSELF AT HIM, JUMPING UP FROM THE OPERATING TABLE AND KNOCKING REEV ASIDE.
(SHOVED) Oof!
(FX: SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS ETC CLATTER TO THE FLOOR AS SHE RUNS OUT. )
(CALLING) Lizzo — Lizzo, come back! You can’t escape. You’re only
postponing the inevitable...
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 7
4. INT. VICE CHANCELLOR’S OFFICE — DAY
CHANCELLOR It takes years of study.
I beg your pardon?
CHANCELLOR
Years and years. As Vice Chancellor of this establishment, I think I can say that without fear of contradiction. So which of you actually wishes to study for their doctorate?
What?
CHANCELLOR
And in what discipline, may I ask? We offer doctorates in most subjects — Logistical Astronomy, Galactic Civilisation, Quantum Nucleonics, Hip-Hop-Hap Theory...
I already have a doctorate. Several, in fact. Some in disciplines that haven’t even been invented yet... Look, Vice Chancellor, let me see if I can explain.
CHANCELLOR Please do. You’re already a doctor, you say?
Not just a doctor.
This is THE Doctor. You invited him here.
CHANCELLOR I did? Oh — THE Doctor? Yes, yes, I did.
To give him an honorary degree.
Which, of course, I shall be delighted to accept.
CHANCELLOR Ah. No.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 8
No?
CHANCELLOR No.
No?!
CHANCELLOR This is where the confusion arises you see.
Not really.
CHANCELLOR It’s tomorrow.
Is it? I’m sure it was today when we arrived.
CHANCELLOR
The Carlos Milhaven awards ceremony is tomorrow. Named after one of our illustrious sponsors. Tomorrow, not today. So I was expecting you tomorrow.
Doctor — we’re a day early.
Yes, thank, you, I’1ll handle this, Peri. Are you saying we are a day early?
CHANCELLOR Precisely.
Well, I do like to be precise.
CHANCELLOR There is a lot to see. As you’re here, you’re very welcome to avail yourself of any or all of our amenities.
Thank you. Come along, Peri — let us avail ourselves.
Thank you, Vice Chancellor. We’ll see you tomorrow.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 9
CHANCELLOR I look forward to it. As, I’m sure, will Professor Baxton.
(IMPRESSED) Professor Baxton? Now she’s something of a legend in academic circles. The galaxy’s foremost Moral Philosopher. Her name is venerated among the cognoscenti.
CHANCELLOR (WARY) You know the professor?
Well, we have met. But it was a long time ago, and I had a different face back then.
CHANCELLOR I’m sorry?
Oh don’t apologise. We’1ll see you tomorrow.
FX: THE DOCTOR SWEEPS OUT.
CHANCELLOR Yes. Either myself or Professor Baxton can sort you out then.
(CALLING BACK) Peri!
Actually, I don’t think anyone can sort the Doctor out.
FX: SHE EXITS.
CHANCELLOR (LOW, SINISTER) Oh, I think we can, young lady. I think we can.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 10
5. EXT. CAMPUS AREA — DAY
FX: AS THEY WALK:
There is something distinctly odd going on here.
Just because they didn’t hang out the bunting and hire the brass band a day early.
I said my timing was precise, Peri, and I meant it. Precisely one day early. Precisely because something is odd.
You mean, you planned for us to arrive early?
Precisely.
But why?
That, my dear Peri, is the question. Ah — perhaps that will help.
What is it?
Information access booth. A bit like tourist information. Only helpful.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 11
6. INT. INFORMATION ACCESS BOOTH — CONTINUOUS
FX: AN ENCLOSED SPACE INSIDE THE SMALL BOOTH.
Incredible — this booth is actually smaller on the inside. Right, let’s see...
FX: BEEPS AND WHIRRS ETC AS THE DOCTOR WORKS THE MACHINE.
You getting anywhere with that?

I most certainly am. All candidates for honorary degrees are nominated through a complicated voting system involving the academic staff and ratified by the governing board. All candidates in the history of the university, except one.
Guess who.
My nomination was pushed through by the Vice Chancellor as a fait accompli.
But, isn’t that a good thing?
Somehow I don’t think so. There is a reason why I was invited here. And it wasn’t to get a degree.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 12
7. EXT. CAMPUS AREA — CONTINUOUS
FX: DOCTOR AND PERI EXIT THE BOOTH.
Whatever they want, it’s something to do with you.
Obviously.
No, I mean — it’s not like they need someone clever.
What exactly are you implying, Miss Brown?
This is a prestigious space university. They have clever people already.
Yes, I do see what you mean.
So it’s you they want. The Doctor, in person.
Accept no substitutes... But how do we discover the truth? I mean clues aren’t just going to wander up to us and ask for [help]
(FX: AS HE SPEAKS, LIZZO RUNS UP — AGITATED, OUT OF BREATH,
FOR HER LIFE.)
Help me — please, help me! They’re after me. Please, I don’t know who’s involved but you’re outsiders, So...
Is it that obvious?
So perhaps I can trust you.
You most certainly can trust us. You’re a Garnantian, aren’t you?
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 13
Yes, but [I need your help]
Thought I recognised the species. Cold-blooded, green scaly skin, the segmented tail...
Doctor — she needs help! She’s terrified — look at her.

Yes, of course. Well, if we can help, we will. This is Peri, and I’m the Doctor — perhaps you’ve heard of me? No? Getting an honorary degree tomorrow? Still no? You’d better tell us all about it, um — what’s your name?
Lizzo. Please — my head hurts...
Let me see.. Who did this to you? These cuts, and these burns — these are exactly the marks a Sidelian Brain Scanner would leave.
I don’t know what it was. I don’t know what they want from me.
Well, that’s easily answered. They want to steal your brain.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 14
8. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY FOYER — CONTINUOUS
(FADE IN. FX: AUTOMATIC DOORS SWOOSH OPEN. THE DOCTOR, PERI AND
ENTER. )
This is the Medical Facility, right? — Well, there’s no-one here now.
They will be looking for me.
So they won’t expect you to find you in here, will they?
I still say we should go to someone in authority. Like the Vice Chancellor.
I don’t know who to trust any more than Lizzo does. The Vice Chancellor could up to his academic eyebrows in whatever is going on. He’s the one who invited me here, remember?
I suppose.
And I want to get a look at the Sidelian equipment. In purely chronological terms, it shouldn’t have been invented yet. Now, Lizzo, where in this Facility did you escape from exactly?
Somewhere on the lower levels. An operating room. They gave me a sedative. I don’t think it was enough.
You felt it?
I escaped.
And you’ve no idea why this student, what did you say his name was? Reev? You’ve no idea why he would have done this to you?
No. He always seemed very friendly. Clever, but quiet.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 15
They’re the worst. And the noisy ones, they’re the worst too.
Let’s see if we can find this operating room, then. You up to that, Lizzo?
I think so.
Good girl.
(FX: MORE DOORS AS THEY GO INSIDE THE FACILITY. FADE THEM AS THEY
There’s an elevator down here.
She means a ‘lift’, Lizzo. It’s all right — I’1l translate for you if we continue to get bombarded with trans-Atlantic inexactitudes...
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 16
9. EXT. CAMPUS AREA — DAY
FX: STUDENTS MILLING ABOUT. REEV RUNS UP.
(URGENT) Anyone seen Lizzo? Anyone?
Oh, hi, Reev. She was at the Geometric Calculus seminar this morning if that helps?
Not really, but thanks... (TO HIMSELF) She might have doubled back. I’1l have to get help...
FX: REEV HURRIES OFF.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 17
10. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY LOWER CORRIDOR — DAY
There’s another room at the end. Looks like some kind of laboratory.
Not an operating room?
Don’t think so.
(GROAN OF PAIN) My head. It feels like it is on fire.
Disadvantage of a cold-blooded species...
Would it help if we bathed your head with cold water?
It might.
Good idea, Peri. We could try that lab.. Aha — or this store room. Might find something useful in here.
FX: STORE ROOM DOOR SLIDES OPEN.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 18
11. INT. STORE ROOM — CONTINUOUS
FX: THEY ENTER.
Mind you don’t trip on the hermetic seal. —
An airtight storeroom? Why?
Chemicals stored here. See, on the shelves?
Good point. — That large cupboard is interesting.
FX: PERI RATTLES THE CUPBOARD DOOR.
It’s locked.
Yes, it would be. But here’s a basin.. Pop the plug in, and... Hmmm, tap’s a bit stiff. Ah!
FX: HE MANAGES TO TURN THE TAP, COLD WATER FLOWING SLOWLY.
(CONT'D) Peri, you must be able to find a hanky in a pocket somewhere.
FX: SOME RUMMAGING, THEN:
Here you are.
Thank you. I did actually mean in one of your own pockets rather than mine. But I suppose we all have to make sacrifices.
FX: WETS HANKY AND BATHES LIZZO’S HEAD. TAP STILL RUNNING.
Thank you, Doctor.
That better?
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 19
It helps.
FX: REEV IS COMING DOWN THE CORRIDOR OUTSIDE.
(LOUD WHISPER) Someone’s coming.
(PANIC) They will find me. They want my brain!
FX: LIZZO RUNS OFF — HEADING AWAY FROM REEV.
(CALLING) No — Lizzo, wait!
FX: THE DOCTOR TURNS OFF THE TAP. IT CREAKS.
(EFFORT) Stupid tap. They need a plumber not a Doctor.
(URGENT) Doctor — Lizzo’s gone. She ran down a side corridor.
That’s it. Right, come on...
(FX: TAP STILL DRIPPING. DOCTOR AND PERI EXIT. DOOR SLIDES SHUT. STAY WITH THE DRIPPING TAP FOR JUST A MOMENT. )
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 20
12. INT. MEDICAL FACILITY LOWER CORRIDOR — CONTINUOUS
We have to get after her.
We certainly do — she’s still got my hanky.
(CALLING) Hey, you two! What are you doing down here? This is a restricted area.
That’s all right. We’re just looking.
Just leaving too. Back to the elevat- the lift?
FX: THEY HEAD DOWN THE CORRIDOR.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 21
13. INT. LIBRARY — DAY
FX: FADE IN. THE DOCTOR AND PERI SPEAK QUIETLY.
‘The Mira Vandweezi Library’. Why should Lizzo be hiding here?
I very much doubt she is.
Then what are we doing here?
She could be hiding anywhere, and we can hardly search the whole campus. No, the best way to help Lizzo now is to find out what’s really going on.
You’re worried about this Sidelian brain thing?
I am. And I don’t want to ruffle too many questions or raise too many feathers before we know a bit more about what we’re dealing with.
Hence the university library.
Indeed. Don’t worry — we’ll find Lizzo.
How? There are no books. How can you have a library with no books?

The books are all digitised. Data and information rather than paper and print. But for what it’s worth, I agree with you. There’s nothing like the smell of a real library — leather binding, yellowing paper, the knowledge of the centuries scratched out on parchment by men of learning...
So where do we start?
University Information System. Here we are.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 22
FX: ELECTRONIC NOISES AS THE DOCTOR WORKS AT A TERMINAL.
Are these all the students?
That’s right. A mini-biog for each. The students are supposed to keep them up to date, and when they leave it forms a record of their time here.
Is Lizzo in there?
Just what I was... Ah yes — here we are. Let’s play the latest entry.
IN THE PLAYBACK LIZZO IS HAPPY, UPBEAT, LAUGHING.

(PLAYBACK) So, my final year. [I can’t believe it. This time next year I’1ll be — well, I don’t know where I’1l1 be. I wonder what Raych and Chanksy and the others will be doing. I’1l miss them — we’ve had some laughs...]
OVER THE SQUARE-BRACKETED SECTION:
She seems so happy.
Yes, she does. Her whole life ahead of her.
I hope she’s all right.
We’ll make sure she is.
(PLAYBACK) ..I’ve got to pass the exams first of course. Though Professor Baxton has predicted me a Highest on her learning stream, which is amazing...
FX: PLAYBACK CLICKS OFF.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 23
That was just a few days ago.
I can’t believe it’s the same person. What happened to her?
FX: VARIOUS DATA RETRIEVAL NOISES AS:
I don’t know... Ah, this is interesting, look — Lizzo’s seminar group, complete with pictures.
Hey, isn’t that —
The rude young man who pushed past us when we arrived, yes. Miklev, apparently. Studying First-Phase Geo-Tolerance and Moral Philosophy.
Maybe we can find him. He might know what’s going on.
My thoughts exactly. At least we know he’s not hiding. Here, take this.
FX: A CLICK AND A BLEEP AS THE DOCTOR REMOVES A DATACUBE.
What is it?
Datacube. I’ve copied Lizzo’s whole journal on to it. Could be useful.
I always meant to keep a journal when I was a student. Never got round to it.
Well there’s plenty of room on the cube if you want to start now. Press your thumb against that red side, and hold it like... so. There. When you’re done just release the pressure, and voila.
Student recording.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 24
Now let’s see if we can track down this Miklev. Why don’t you have a look outside? This library seems to be at a major junction of all the footpaths — you never know, he might wander past.
Like before. What about you?
I’ll see if I can call up his timetable on this terminal. I shan’t be long...
FX: A RATHER ‘NEGATIVE’ BLEEP FROM THE TERMINAL.
(CONT’D) I hope...
Yeah, right. I’1ll see you soon.
FX: MORE DOWNBEAT TERMINAL NOISES. PERI LEAVES.
Yes, I know I’m not authorised, you stupid machine... That’s why I’m bypassing the security systems...
FX: AN ALARM.
‘SH’ IRRITABLY
(CONT’D)
(SIGHS) Typical. Just typical. (CALLING) Sorry, everyone. Sorry — I think I pressed the wrong button. Nothing nefarious, nothing suspicious... Um, could someone...?
FX: THE ALARM CUTS OUT.
There you are. That should be fine now. If I can do anything else to help — (just say)
Indeed you can. — Miklev, isn’t it?
That’s right. Hey, didn’t I see you earlier? When I was late for the Quantum Redaction seminar?
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 25
You certainly did. I wonder if I could have a quick word with
you...
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 26
14. EXT. OUTSIDE THE LIBRARY — DAY
(FX: WE JOIN PERI MID-WAY THROUGH RECORDING HER ‘LOG’. FAINT ‘WHIRR’ OF THE RECORDER: )

. If I even see college again. I somehow doubt they’1ll have kept my place open for all these years. Guess I’d be a mature student now. — But travelling with the Doctor is certainly an education. It’s like doing social service too, I guess. We help people. There are a lot of people who need helping. For all his brashness and posturing, the Doctor always stands up for what’s right. Truth, justice, and the Gallifreyan way. He doesn’t seem to care that one day it might get him killed. Actually, I’ve seen him die. He died for me. He thought I was worth saving. I sometimes wonder if one day, I’1l end up returning the favour. This is crazy, it’s like I’m writing my own obituary. Oh — here he comes now. Cue danger and excitement.
FX: PERI CLICKS OFF THE CUBE. THE DOCTOR ARRIVES, WITH MIKLEV.
Peri — meet Miklev.
Hi there.
Um, hello.
Miklev was telling me he knows our mutual friend Lizzo.
Really?
Well, we’re in the same lecture group. I see her around.
When did you last see her?
This morning, like I told the Doctor. She seemed fine. I don’t know why you’re worried about her.
She just seemed a little ‘down’ when we saw her.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 27
She was OK at the seminar. It’s funny, Reev was looking for her just now as well.
Reev? But that’s — (the student who attacked Lizzo)
Yes, Peri.. And you haven’t seen Lizzo since then.
Actually, yes. Talking of Reev reminds me — she had to go and do an extra test, I think.
What’s that got to do with Reev?
Just that he took the test a while back. A few of the students have done it recently.
Have you taken this extra test?
No, not me. It’s the brainy ones who get selected.
And then they return to their normal curriculum afterwards?
Yes, why wouldn’t they?
No reason. No reason at all.
Though... Well, don’t tell anyone I said so, but with some of them... Like Reev...
What?
It does go to their heads a bit.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 28
Their heads?
Well, they hang out together, ignore the rest of us — even people who used to be friends. I got on all right with Reev, but since he took the test he just blanks me.
Sounds like this test isn’t a good thing.
A couple of the quieter ones, who wouldn’t say boo to a gastropod, have really come out of themselves. Maybe that’s a good thing?
A personality change?

I’ll say. Shy and retiring one day, partying like there’s no tomorrow the next. Look, sorry — I have to go, I’ve got a lecture with Professor Baxton over in H7. If Lizzo’s there, I’1l tell her you’re looking for her. Catch you later, yeah?
Yeah.
(MIMICKING) Yeah.
FX: MIKLEV HURRIES OFF.
(CONT'D) Come on then, Peri.
Where to?
H7 of course. It’s a long shot, but if Lizzo should be at that lecture... maybe she’1l show up...
FADE OUT AS THEY FOLLOW MIKLEV.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 29
15. EXT. CAMPUS AREA — DAY
(FX: LIZZO BREATHING HEAVILY — FRIGHTENED AND EXHAUSTED.
(OFF, CALLING) Sure she must have come this way.
(TO HERSELF) Oh no. Not again. I can’t...
(OFF) There she is! Come on, before she gets away.
FX: LIZZO RUNS FOR IT. BUT THE STUDENTS CATCH HER — A SCUFFLE.
Let me go — please let me go!
No chance. We have some unfinished business. In the Medical Facility.
No — no, please!
FX: THEY DRAG THE PROTESTING LIZZO AWAY.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 30
16. INT. LECTURE THEATRE — DAY
(FX: FADE IN. WE ARE AT THE END OF A LECTURE, STUDENTS GETTING RESTLESS. DOCTOR AND PERI SIDLE IN THROUGH A DOOR AS BAXTON SPEAKS. )
.The application of Chaos Theory places an additional burden on Moral Philosophy.
(ASIDE) That’s Professor Baxton?
(STARTLED) It... would appear so, yes.
(NB: THE DOCTOR HAS RECOGNISED THE RANI. BUT UNTIL HE KNOWS WHAT SHE’S UP TO, HE’S NOT LETTING ON TO PERI.)

If there are indeed patterns in apparently random events as diverse as the formation of a snowflake or the flow of galactic traffic round the Horsehead Nebula excursion route, then can we be certain that any decision we make truly be our own?
Still no sign of Lizzo. The place is packed — guess she must be an impressive speaker.
True enough. Though I have to say she’s not entirely as I remember...
There’s time for a couple of questions if anyone has... You?!
(SHE IS THROWN FOR A MOMENT — THIS ISN’T THE INCARNATION OF THE
SHE WAS EXPECTING. BUT SHE COVERS QUICKLY: )
Er, yes — you, by the door. The mature student in the ‘interesting’ coat.
(PITCHED UP) ‘Mature’? — Yes, well.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 31
(LOW) This could be embarrassing. Maybe I should preserve it for posterity.
FX: FAINT ‘WHIRR’ AS PERI RECORDS THIS...
(NB: UNDERCURRENT TO FOLLOWING: THE DOCTOR AND ‘BAXTON’ EACH KNOW WHO THE OTHER REALLY IS, BUT PLAY ALONG. )

You appear to imply that Chaos Theory might somehow influence our individual decisions. If your contention is that we’re not responsible for our own actions, or even thoughts, aren’t you rather ducking the issue of morality?
Am I?

I believe so. If nothing else, I’d have thought an academic of your reputation and calibre would have an opinion on the whole question of whether the end justifies the means, rather than ascribing it all to the ebb and flow of the universe. Perhaps you could tell us exactly where you stand on the issue? Hmm?

Or perhaps I think my opinions are my own business, and each and every student should be allowed to make up their own minds. It was you who brought up freedom of choice, I think. — Does anyone have a less specious query?
(LOW) That told you.
Nobody? — (SIGH; WHAT A BUNCH OF DULLARDS) Very well. Until next time. Lecture over.
(FX: CLATTERING AS STUDENTS GET UP EN MASSE AND BEGIN TO EXIT.
CLICKS OFF HER RECORDING. )
Well that was... interesting. But it doesn’t help us find Lizzo.
No. But it was most enlightening, all the same.
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 32
17. INT. STORE ROOM — DAY
(FX: THE TAP IS STILL DRIPPING, NOW INTO A FULL SINK.
SLOSHES TO THE FLOOR...)
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 33
18. INT. FOYER OUTSIDE THE LECTURE THEATRE — DAY
FX: STUDENTS PASSING BY.
So what’s our next move?
I think I’1l check the university records and find out what these tests for the gifted and talented students really are.
How can you do that?
Talk to the Vice Chancellor. Or his computer at least. If the tests are bona fide, there’ll be records. And if not...
If not?
I’1ll tell you later.
You don’t want [me to come with you?]
I’1ll be less conspicuous on my own.
That’s a matter of opinion.. (BRIGHTLY) Why don’t I go talk to Professor Baxton? She might know something about [the tests. ]
(QUICKLY) No! — No, Peri, I think it’s probably best to keep out of the Professor’s way for now.
But if she knows something that could help...?
We’ve already drawn quite enough attention to ourselves for the moment. Let me speak to the Vice Chancellor first.
Well, one of us has. Look, Doctor — [all I want to do...]
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 34
Peri!
All right. I’ll meet you back at the Library.
I won’t be long, I promise. (WALKING, CALLING BACK) But be careful. There’s something very wrong here.
HE'S GONE
(TO HERSELF) That’s if I can remember the way to the Library. All these plazas look the same to — (BREAKS OFF) Oh look, there’s
Professor Baxton!
FX: STAY WITH PERI AS SHE FOLLOWS BAXTON.
(CALLING) Professor! Professor Baxton, can I just have a moment?
(STOPPING) Hello. Another of my mature students, are you?
(SLIGHTLY MIFFED) Er, no. — But I was at your lecture.
Oh yes. With the rather forthright gentleman.
I had a few questions. About the lecture...
You'll have to wait until next time, I’m afraid. Life’s too short for one thing, and for another I have an appointment at the Medical Facility. So if you’1ll excuse me.
FX: BAXTON HURRIES OFF, LEAVING PERI BEHIND.
But why would you be going... (QUIETER, AS BAXTON’S GONE) .. to the Medical Facility?
FX: SHE HURRIES OFF AFTER BAXTON. FADE TO:
THE RANI ELITE by Justin Richards (FINAL) Page 35
19. INT. VICE CHANCELLOR’S OFFICE — DAY
